data.title: Editor’s letter: Zeenat Aman is in a class of her own | Vogue India
data.meta_description: Vogue India’s Head of Editorial Content, Megha Kapoor, introduces the July-August 2023 issue starring Zeenat Aman
data.text:
Words matter and Zeenat Aman is a wordsmith.

We tend to forget the power of words in this climate of clickbait, where attention spans have dwindled to a bite-sized 30 seconds and 50-character captions. To say I was thrilled when the legendary Zeenat agreed to be on our July-August cover would be an understatement. And when she agreed to pen the accompanying story herself, I was overjoyed. Then I read her piece. A meandering soliloquy that moves from her relationship with fame to social media, from self-image to style, from her love for her family to her dreams and her life, causing the reader to be overcome by nostalgia, wisdom and hope all at once.

Having had the pleasure and privilege of styling Zeenat for this story, lensed by Avani Rai, I was graced with a subject in her seventies, chic in monochromatic looks from Sabyasachi, Raw Mango and Amit Aggarwal (all paired with flats because it’s cool to be comfortable). It became apparent very early on the set that Zeenat moved with—and possessed—more style in her pinky than many a seasoned pro I’ve encountered.

She has always been an icon. Her repertoire of films, from Haré Rama Haré Krishna (1971) and Yaadon Ki Baaraat (1973) to Satyam Shivam Sundaram (1978), Don (1978) and Qurbani (1980), and that fresh-faced, sassy, drop-dead gorgeous appeal have seen her referenced on countless mood boards (the image of her in that silver sequin gown that she was literally sewn into is inimitable). However, since her Instagram debut in February this year, she has become the thinking person’s style icon. Her feed is a consummate mix of a peek into her current life, dogs and daily happenings, as well as a treasure trove of old photos and clips from her younger days as a Bollywood legend. Images aside, which in and of themselves are stalk-worthy, it’s her insightful and intelligent captions that have captivated people everywhere.

While, as she puts it, “There is enough blather in the world,” we thank you, Zeenat, for your words, which are anything but.

Photographed by Avani Rai
